author: @statquest
text: Correction: 15:21 The left hand side of the equation should be ‚Äúlog(odds Obesity)‚Äù instead of ‚Äúsize‚Äù.  NOTE: In statistics, machine learning and most programming languages, the default base for the log() function is 'e'. In other words, when I write, "log()", I mean "natural log()", or "ln()". Thus, the log to the base 'e' of 2.717 = 1. author: @user-mn8th3ie1t
text: A very informative video. A slight observation re.terminology. In any regression modelling, Let‚Äôs take your example of predicting size of a mouse using weight as a predictor, what you‚Äôre actually predicting is not the size of a mouse, but the expected size of a mouse given its weight         E[size /weight] = intercept + b0*weight. It‚Äôs crucial to introduce that probabilistic reasoning at an early stage. The idea that we‚Äôre trying to predict the expected value of the target variable given the value of a predictor, independent variable, betrays the method that we want to find the regression coefficient of weight that would render observing the size most likely, hence the famous MLE - Maximum Likelihood Estimation.

author: @ashishmehra5143
text: Folks who do not understand the standard error:  It identifies the variation in the sample. It tells how much the sample mean will vary from the population mean. Standard error is used to calculate the Confidence Interval. Standard error is inversely proportional to sample size, that is s.e. ‚àù 1/n  The formula is: s/‚àön 	where: 	s = Sample standard deviation 	n = Sample size

author: @karannchew2534
text: Notes for future revision.  08:10  *Squiggly line = Probability view.* (Probability vs variable values) Y = 1 / (1+exp(-(Œ≤o+Œ≤1x1+..)))  *Straight line = Coefficient view.* (log(odd) vs variable values) Y = Œ≤o + Œ≤1x1 + ...  Squiggly line Y=0.5 ‚áÑ Straight line Y=0 Straight line slope ‚áÑ Squiggly line ??   ---- 14:26 Categorical variable  Still, *Straight line = Coefficient view.* (log(odd) vs variable values) But, because the X is categorical, we use delta between the variables for X.   Linear Regression Continuous Y vs  categorical X ‚áÑ Continuous Y vs  categorical X and X delta Y = B1 x mean_var1 + B2 x delta_mean_var12  Logistic Regression: Probability Y vs categorical X variables ‚áÑ Log Odd Y vs categorical X variables ‚áÑ Log Odd Y vs categorical X and X delta  In log world, delta ‚áÑ ratio  Y = B1 x log(Odd_Obesity_var1) + B2 x delta_log(Odd_var1)_log(Odd_var2) = B1 x log(Odd_Obesity_var1) + B2 x log(Odd_var1/Odd_var2 ratio)  17:45 Therefore, in logistics regression results, the coefficient Œ≤2 applies to log(odd_var1 / odd_var2) i.e. log(odd ratio).  X1 is log(odd ratio), not var2, count of var2, mean of var2 etc.

author: @robwasab
text: Hi, I thought your explanation of logistic regression using discrete variables was unclear.  I think you could've explained it without having to go into t-tests, and should've focused on drawing analogies between discrete and continuous logistic regression, since we just covered continuous, and it would've helped reinforce the concept. The final presentation of the discrete formula for probability was confusing, since you left it in linear form, this was compounded by declaring that the formula results in 'size', as in obesity, but the formula is actually computing log(odds of obesity), which is unit-less, and that you need to use the linear coefficients to arrive at the non-linear probability distribution. It would have been nice if you made it clear that the discrete logistic regression is just the continuous one with its input predictor held to 0 or 1. Pretty simple. This tells me that I can just recycle my continuous knowledge for discrete.  Another thing that you could've made clear is that odds is different from probability. And that odds is p / (1 - p).   Also, I would've liked if you finished the conversation on how to compute the actual probability distribution once we've found the linear regression coefficients for both continuous and discrete cases.  Thanks for your effort put into these videos, hope these comments are productive.

author: @jiayiwu4101
text: In summary, there are five graphs/function within logistic regression. 1. p-odds: y = odds = p/(1-p). this is a part of inverse function p belongs to [0,1] and odds belongs to [0,inf). Two parts are p<1/2 + p>1/2 2. odds-log(odds): y = log(odds) this is a normal log function where odds belongs to [0,inf) and log(odds) belongs to (-inf,+inf). Corresponding two parts are 0<odds<1 + odds>=1 3. (3=1+2) p-log(odds): y= log(odds) = log(p/1/p). This is the famous logit function where p belongs to [0,1] and log(odds) belongs to (-inf,+inf). Corresponding two parts are p<1/2 + p>1/2 4. (inverse 3) x-p: p = 1/(1+(e^(-z)). This is the famous sigmoid function and it is the inverse of 3rd relationship, where z=ax+b or x belongs to (-inf,+inf) and p belongs to [0,1]. Corresponding two parts are z<-log2 + z>-log2 5. (5=3+4) x-log(odds): log(odds)=log(p/1-p)=z=ax+b. This is eventually the logistic model where z or x belongs to (-inf,+inf) and log(odds) belongs to (-inf,+inf). Corresponding parts are z<-log2 + z>-logs.  Thank you Prof! I finally got how this method were invented and how smart those people were!!

author: @mostinho7
text: 4:50 in linear regression, y axis can have any value (which makes it easier to solve) but for logistic regression y values confined between 0 and 1 as it represents the probability. To deal with this, we transform the y axis to be log odds instead of probability Transforming probability to log odds using the logit function, logit = log(p/(1-p)) 5:50 how the axis changes The old y axis (in probability) that went from 0.5 to 1 goes to 0 to infinity (in log odds) 8:00 the log odds y axis transforms the curved plot to a linear plot 8:20 the coefficients of logistic regression are for the linear plot of log odds axis 8:48 you get coefficients of the kind just like linear regression 9:30 don‚Äôt understand, check odds ratio stat quest

author: @statquest
text: Correction: 15:21 The left hand side of the equation should be ‚Äúlog(odds Obesity)‚Äù instead of ‚Äúsize‚Äù.  NOTE: In statistics, machine learning and most programming languages, the default base for the log() function is 'e'. In other words, when I write, "log()", I mean "natural log()", or "ln()". Thus, the log to the base 'e' of 2.717 = 1.  Support StatQuest by buying my book The StatQuest Illustrated Guide to Machine Learning or a Study Guide or Merch!!! https://statquest.org/statquest-store/
